{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3420983,"name":"","username":"Andrew431","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/e99b99/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-05T20:51:14.813Z","cooked":"

I was wondering that, when using a thrust/radial/thrust bearing stack for a turret, do the thrust bearings’ innermost pads scrape against the shaft/screw or the inner race of the radial bearing (or does the inner race scrape against the shaft)?
Example of such a bearing stack:

Section view: red is stationary, green is moving, purple is stationary(?) and red arrows point to surfaces that I think may scrape against each other.

image460×593 65.8 KB

I also saw some designs made from 3 radial bearings with shims between the inner races so they do not contact each other and it seems to not have this issue. Is this scraping causing sufficient friction/wear for it to be a problem or is the relatively limited rotation of a turret not that much of a concern?

Oğuz Özgür","username":"oguzozgur","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oguzozgur/{size}/229514_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-05T21:09:00.929Z","cooked":"

I never used a thrust bearing setup, but if the thing you are squeezing is slightly thicker than the middle bearing, scraping should be minimal to none. Not sure if it is the right way to do it, just my guess.

Oğuz Özgür","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53023,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9483"},"post_url":"/t/thrust-bearings-in-bearing-stack-sandwich/470780/2","custom_user_title":"9483","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3421003,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-05T21:41:02.154Z","cooked":"

There will be some clearance between the thrust washers and the correctly sized shaft. Note that these are NOT sealed.
You will need to be careful that you don’t tighten your bolt to the point that the thrust bearings seize up. Also, use a locknut… Otherwise it will come loose.
The other method allows you to cinch the whole stack up tight. Feels like a better choice.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-09-05T21:41:02.154Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":185,"readers_count":184,"score":92.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470780,"topic_slug":"thrust-bearings-in-bearing-stack-sandwich","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/thrust-bearings-in-bearing-stack-sandwich/470780/3","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3421008,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-05T22:14:17.220Z","cooked":"

I would personally just use radial ball bearings (deep groove if available for a similar cost, avoid metric if possible (tend to have closer OD to ID measurements)) and stack things up. Sure there is an argument to be made you are not loading things correctly, but just use more bearing stacks than you think you need (odd number to get around the turret ring plate being out of round, learned that the hard way in 2020). The point here is to not over-constrain the physical artifact (because nothing matches CAD perfectly)

Other things you can do is play with the mass distribution of the turret itself to avoid shock moment loads. No thrust bearing necessary. (Wanna see something wild? 503 in 2022)

Two flanged bearings can be used in place of 3 bearings where space is a concern, tradeoff is the turret ring plate thickness is set by the bearings and you need more stacks (or a second ring elsewhere) to support because the flange isn’t particularly larger than the OD of the bearing.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-09-05T22:37:41.684Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":74.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470780,"topic_slug":"thrust-bearings-in-bearing-stack-sandwich","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thebluealliance.com/team/503/2022","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Frog Force - Team 503 (2022) - The Blue Alliance","clicks":28}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/thrust-bearings-in-bearing-stack-sandwich/470780/4","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3421033,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-05T23:53:00.396Z","cooked":"

There’s actually a second scraping mode, in which the thrust washers can scrape against the stationary plate because they are washers rolling on the surface at multiple points in multiple directions instead of individual balls or rollers.

I generally prefer the single large xcontact bearing setup because they have fewer moving parts, and are generally stiffer with less play due to less tolerance stackup.

Small angular contact bearings might be an interesting option here if you don’t wanna go for a single large xcontact bearings as they are good at combined radial-thrust loads when used properly and won’t experience scraping, which should allow more pre-load to take out the play in the bearing stacks

Skyehawk:

(Wanna see something wild? 503 in 2022 )

503 also had incredibly poor turret stiffness and is something I would not suggest copying for that reason alone, with the shooting applying extremely high moments. Their turret top recoils more than the base plate which is likely caused due to the bearing setup.
